feed.title: NewsTracker: snowden
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Britain pulls out spies as Russia, China crack Snowden files: report
entry.summary: The revelations about the impact of Snowden on intelligence operations comes days after Britain's terrorism law watchdog said the rules governing the security services' abilities to spy on the public needed to be overhauled.

entry.title: Britain pulls out spies as Russia, China reportedly crack Snowden files
entry.summary: Mr Snowden downloaded more than 1.7 million secret files from security agencies in the US and Britain in 2013, and leaked details about mass surveillance of phone and internet communications.

entry.title: Britain forced to withdraw spies after Russia and China access secret information stolen by US whistleblower Edward Snowden
entry.summary:
Snowden triggered a wave of controversy when he leaked tens of thousands of documents about surveillance programmes run by the NSA and foreign counterparts, including Britain's GCHQ, in 2013.

The revelation came with renewed focus on s py agencies' powers to collect communications data in bulk, after a review - commissioned in the wake of the Snowden revelations - said the framework was "undemocratic" and must be entirely rewritten.

entry.title: UK spies 'moved over Snowden files'
entry.summary: Mr Snowden leaked data two years ago.

entry.title: Britain moves spies as Russia cracks Snowden files
entry.summary:
Britain has been forced to remove some of its spies after Russia and China accessed the top-secret raft of documents taken by former US intelligence contractor Edward Snowden, British media have reported.

Mr Snowden fled to Russia after leaking the documents to the press in 2013 to expose the extent of US online surveillance programmes and to protect "privacy and basic liberties".

entry.title: Britain pulls spies as Moscow cracks Snowden files: reports
entry.summary: Snowden worked as a contractor at the CIA and National Security Agency, where he was able to download 1.7 million secret documents that showed how hundreds of millions of people had been under surveillance by the authorities.

entry.title: UK Withdraws Spies Over Snowden Files
entry.summary: "Snowden has done incalculable damage. In some cases the agencies have been forced to intervene and lift their agents from operations to prevent them from being identified and killed."

entry.title: Britain pulls out spies as Russia, China crack Snowden files - report
entry.summary: The United States wants Snowden to stand trial after he leaked classified documents, fled the country and was eventually granted asylum in Moscow in 2013.

entry.title: Britain pulls out spies as Russia, China crack Snowden files- report
UK spies 'moved over Snowden files'
entry.summary: According to the Sunday Times, Western intelligence agencies have been forced to pull agents out of "hostile countries" after "Moscow gained access to more than one million classified files" held by Mr Snowden.

entry.title: UK Withdraws Spies Over Snowden Files
entry.summary: A British intelligence source was quoted as saying: "We know Russia and China have access to Snowden's material and will be going through it for years to come, searching for clues to identify potential targets.

entry.title: Britain forced to withdraw spies after Russia and China access files stolen by US whistleblower Edward Snowden
Oliver Stone's 'Snowden' filming at locations around DC
entry.summary:
Film crews have been spotted near the White House and in the Tryst coffee shop in Adams Morgan that Snowden frequented.

Stone is adapting the book "The Snowden Files: The Inside Story of the World's Most Wanted Man" by Guardian journalist Luke Harding for the screen.

Stone has called the Snowden case "one of the great stories of our time."

Sony Pictures purchased the big-screen rights to Glenn Greenwald's "No Place to Hide: Edward Snowden, the NSA and the U.S. Surveillance State."

entry.title: US secretly expanded warrantless NSA internet spying to find hackers, Snowden documents show
US: Don't let defense utter 'Snowden' to jurors
entry.summary: It was Snowden who disclosed how that court secretly approved expanded U.S. surveillance methods.

entry.title: US in Chicago terrorism case: Don't let defense utter 'Snowden' name in jurors' presence
entry.summary:
CHICAGO - Prosecutors want a federal judge in a Chicago terrorism case to prohibit the defense from mentioning Edward Snowden at a 21-year-old suspect's upcoming trial.

Prosecutors worry the defense could seek to blurt out Snowden's name and related topics at Daoud's July trial.

entry.title: Leaks were worth it, says snowden
Snowden awarded freedom of expression prize in Norway
entry.summary:
Snowden, a former analyst at the US National Security Agency, has lived in exile in Russia since 2013 after revealing mass spying programmes by the United States and its allies.

Snowden was awarded Sweden's Right Livelihood Award in 2014 but chose to accept it by video link rather than leaving his exile in Russia.

entry.title: Snowden awarded freedom of expression prize in Norway
entry.summary: OSLO: Former security contractor Edward Snowden won a Norwegian prize for freedom of expression Tuesday and received yet another invitation to leave his exile and receive the award in person.

entry.title: In wake of Snowden leaks, NSA domestic spy program limits pass Congress
In wake of Snowden leaks, NSA domestic spy program limits pass Congress
entry.summary:
Edward Snowden is credited with sparking the debate which has led to reform of surveillance in the US.

Reversing US security policy that had been in place since shortly after the September 11, 2001, attacks, the bill would end a system exposed by former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden in 2013.

entry.title: In wake of Snowden leaks, NSA domestic spy program limits pass Congress
entry.summary:
Passage of the bill is the first major legislative reform of US surveillance practices since Mr Snowden's revelations two years ago this month.

Privacy advocates who have opposed the phone records program since Mr Snowden exposed it balked at the amendments.

entry.title: Obama administration still wants to prosecute Snowden despite surveillance debate
entry.summary: "That's why we believe Mr. Snowden should return to the United States, and he will have the opportunity if he were to return to the United States to make that case in a court of law," said Earnest.

entry.title: Gordon-Levitt has high hopes for impact of 'Snowden'
entry.summary: "Snowden" is set for release in December 2015.

entry.title: Gordon-Levitt has high hopes for impact of 'Snowden'
entry.summary:
LOS ANGELES (AP) - Joseph Gordon-Levitt has big expectations for the impact of "Snowden."

Gordon-Levitt plays Snowden in Stone's film, which is based on two books about the leaks and also features Shailene Woodley, Zachary Quinto and Melissa Leo.

Gordon-Levitt declined to say whether he'd been in contact with Snowden.

entry.title: Chris Christie: Rand Paul is "siding with" Edward Snowden
Activists ticketed for putting Snowden bust on NYC monument
entry.summary:
Two activists who put a bust of Edward Snowden on a Revolutionary War memorial were ticketed and got their confiscated sculpture back Wednesday, saying they felt the episode had sparked conversation about freedom.

"The ideal that Snowden seemed to be fighting for with his actions seemed to be in line with the ideals the revolutionaries, who might also have been called traitors, were fighting for," Tider said by phone.

entry.title: Artists who put Ed Snowden bust on NYC monument are ticketed
entry.summary: The bust's creators said in a statement Wednesday that they wanted to "help the public have an important national debate about mass surveillance" and provide an alternative view of Snowden, whom they feel the media have vilified.

entry.title: Artists who put Ed Snowden bust on NYC monument are ticketed
entry.summary: Snowden is living in exile in Russia after divulging the secret U.S. government collection of phone records, among other intelligence gathering.

entry.title: Artists who put Ed Snowden bust on NYC monument are ticketed
entry.summary: NEW YORK (AP) - The mystery artists who put a bust of Edward Snowden on a Revolutionary War memorial have been ticketed but not criminally charged, and the city has given back their confiscated statue, their lawyer said Wednesday.

entry.title: Snowden injury-free and returning to form
entry.summary:
Newcastle prop Kade Snowden says he's injury-free for the first time in four years and happy to be back in the representative frame.

Snowden is now back where it all began - with NSW Country.

entry.title: Artists to NYPD: Return Edward Snowden Bust We Put in Park
entry.summary: The mysterious artists who planted a bust of Edward Snowden on a Revolutionary War monument now want to free their sculpture from police custody and display it again, saying it was intended as a thought-provoking "gift to the city."

entry.title: Artists to NYPD: Return Edward Snowden bust we put in park
entry.summary: Parks activist Geoffrey Croft feels the bust deserves a place in the city's public space, regardless how viewers may feel about Snowden.

entry.title: Artists to NYPD: Return Edward Snowden bust we put in park
entry.summary: For now, downtown Manhattan gallery Postmasters hopes to show the Snowden bust next month.

entry.title: Artists to NYPD: Return Edward Snowden bust we put on park's Revolutionary War monument
First look at Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Shailene Woodley filming Oliver Stone's Snowden in Washington, D.C.
entry.summary: First look at Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Shailene Woodley filming Oliver Stone's Snowden in Washington, D.C.

entry.title: Busted! Guerrilla artists sneak giant sculpture of Edward Snowden's head into Brooklyn park only to have it pulled down hours later by city workers
entry.summary: 'If you look at history, the people we honor with statues now - certainly the people rebelling against the British rules - were criminals one day,' the creators of the Snowden bust told Mashable.

entry.title: Statue that cast Edward Snowden as a hero removed and held by New York police
entry.summary:
New York City Parks workers work to remove a covered large molded bust of Edward Snowden at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn.

But two of the artists behind the sculpture, who spoke to Fairfax Media on condition of anonymity, hope that its presence, however fleeting, will help spark conversation about Snowden, surveillance and the American ideals they say he was fighting for.

"We were both dismayed that Snowden and the ideals that his actions represent haven't gotten more traction in mainstream media," one of the artists said.

"It's not just Snowden, it's Bradley [now Chelsea] Manning and every other whistleblower whose fighting for the ideals this nation was founded upon. Snowden is an easy representation to use, so we used his visual."

entry.title: Bust of Edward Snowden sneaked into, removed from NYC park
entry.summary: After several mysterious artists put a sculpted bust of Snowden on a New York City war memorial, parks officials have ordered the bust removed.

entry.title: Bust of Edward Snowden sneaked into, removed from NYC park
entry.summary: Animal New York, a city news website, reported that the activists sneaked the 4-foot-tall, 100-pound bust of Snowden before dawn Monday.

entry.title: Bust of whistleblower Edward Snowden sneaked into New York City park; its display short-lived
entry.summary: Snowden's artistic appearance was short-lived.

entry.title: Bust of Edward Snowden Sneaked Into, Removed From NYC Park
entry.summary:
Suddenly, in the middle of the New York night, Edward Snowden's face appeared - deep in a public park.

At daybreak, police said city parks officials ordered the sculpted Snowden removed.

entry.title: Snowden cover-up: Unauthorized bust in Brooklyn becomes martyr to cause
entry.summary: "It would be a dishonor to those memorialized here to not laud those who protect the ideals they fought for, as Edward Snowden has by bringing the NSA's 4th-Amendment-violating surveillance programs to light.

entry.title: John Oliver interviewsï¿½Edward Snowden, and real journalism breaks out
Snowden Talks Surveillance, Hot Pockets with John Oliver
entry.summary: "That is a problem," Snowden conceded.

entry.title: John Oliver, Edward Snowden have a Frost/Nixon moment
entry.summary:
The comedian asked Snowden if he had read every document he leaked and fired back when Snowden replied that he understands what he turned over.

He also confronted Snowden about the New York Times publishing information he provided that may have compromised an operation in Iraq.

"That is a problem," Snowden acknowledged.

Oliver eventually moved on to somewhat lighter fare, showing man-on-the street reactions by Americans who don't know who Snowden is and reacting to the news that the NSA is able to collect some of the naked selfies Americans send each other in a database.

entry.title: John Oliver interviews Edward Snowden, and real journalism breaks out
entry.summary: Oliver pushed hard against Snowden, whom he described as "the most famous hero and/or traitor in recent American history," with a particular focus on Snowden's decision to leak unredacted documents.

entry.title: John Oliver grills Edward Snowden
entry.summary: "You will never be completely free from risk if you if you're free. The only time you can be free from risk are if you're in prison," Snowden said.

entry.title: John Oliver grills Edward Snowden
entry.summary: "I've evaluated all of the documents that are in the archive," Snowden replied.

entry.title: John Oliver grills Edward Snowden over potentially harmful NSA leaks
entry.summary: "The good news is there's no program named 'The D--- Pic program,'" Snowden said.

entry.title: Watch: John Oliver discusses NSA, penis pics with Edward Snowden on 'Last Week Tonight'
entry.summary:
Then Oliver revealed his coup to a delighted audience -- a secretive one-on-one interview with Snowden in Russia, which seemed as if it might not come to pass after Snowden was late to their meeting.

Thankfully, Snowden finally arrived and the duo shared a frank, funny and wide-ranging discussion about everything from NSA programs to the leak of phallic photos.

entry.title: WATCH: John Oliver grills Edward Snowden on 'Last Week Tonight'
entry.summary: John Oliver and Edward Snowden.

entry.title: Britain spied on Argentina over Falklands: Snowden
ACLU: Snowden proved NSA Internet spying harms Americans
ACLU: Snowden proved NSA Internet spying harms Americans
entry.summary:
"We believe the Snowden disclosures will make an immense difference in how this case will play out," Toomey said.

Wikipedia was included on an NSA slide Snowden leaked in 2013 that demonstrated the agency's interest in monitoring communications on certain websites.

Mark Rumold, an attorney for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, said Snowden's disclosures could certainly bolster ACLU's argument, but the state secret privilege remains a challenge.

"Snowden's disclosures have absolutely changed the playing field, but the playing field is not level."

entry.title: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade, claim Edward Snowden papers
entry.summary: The Intercept has in the past published a number of reports from documents released by whistleblower Snowden.

entry.title: CIA worked to break into Apple devices for years ? Snowden docs
Snowden: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade
entry.summary: Both companies said the moves were aimed at protecting the privacy of users of their products and that this was partly a response to wide scale U.S. government spying on Internet users revealed by Snowden in the summer of 2013.

entry.title: News24.com | Snowden says he'd like to return to Geneva
entry.summary: Snowden, aged 31, reiterated that he would not return to the United States unless offered a "fair trial".

entry.title: Snowden: Asylum In Switzerland A 'Great Political Option'
entry.summary: Edward Snowden wants Switzerland to grant him asylum.

entry.title: New Zealand spying on South Pacific neighbors, Snowden documents show
New Zealand shared spy data on Pacific states with allies, Snowden documents allege
entry.summary: The role of the agency, which has a large eavesdropping facility at the top of the country's South Island, was an issue in last year's general election, with documents released by Snowden suggesting the GCSB was planning to conduct mass domestic surveillance.

entry.title: News24.com | Snowden in talks on returning home - lawyer
entry.summary: Kucherena said last August Snowden had been granted a three-year residence permit in Russia.

entry.title: Joseph Gordon-Levitt shares first photo as Edward Snowden
Lawyer: NSA leaker Edward Snowden wants to return home
entry.summary:
Snowden's Russian lawyer, Anatoly Kucherena, said Tuesday March 3, 2015 he was eager to return to the U.S. if given security guarantees, and German and U.S. lawyers were working on the issue.

MOSCOW (AP) - NSA systems analyst Edward Snowden wants to return to the United States from Russia if he's guaranteed a fair trial, his Russian lawyer said Tuesday.

entry.title: Lawyer: NSA leaker Edward Snowden wants to return home
entry.summary: Snowden's whereabouts have not been made public.

entry.title: Lawyer: Edward Snowden Wants To Return Home
Fugitive ex-U.S. spy Snowden in talks on returning home: Lawyer
entry.summary:
Snowden's lawyer, Anatoly Kucherena, who has links to the Kremlin, was speaking at a news conference to present a book he has written about his client.

The United States wants Snowden to stand trial for leaking extensive secrets of electronic surveillance programmes by the National Security Agency (NSA).

entry.title: Snowden in talks on returning to U.S., Russian lawyer says
entry.summary:
Snowden has said in the past he would like to return home if he was assured he would be given a fair trial.

A deeply divisive figure, Snowden is praised by some as a civil rights campaigner and whistleblower and condemned by others as a traitor who had compromised U.S. security.

entry.title: Snowden leak: NSA helped British steal cell phone codes
entry.summary: Still, the methods in this case may prove controversial, as did earlier Snowden revelations that the NSA was hacking transmissions among Google's data centers.
